thread.title: Lower North Island piggery made infamous by comedian Mike King burns to the ground
thread.title_full: Lower North Island piggery made infamous by comedian Mike King burns to the ground

author: Damian George
title: Lower North Island piggery made infamous by comedian Mike King burns to the ground
text:
Lower North Island piggery made infamous by comedian Mike King burns to the ground DAMIAN GEORGE Last updated 13:23, February 25 2017 Chris Wilson 
An abandoned piggery near Levin was burnt to the ground. 
A piggery made infamous by comedian Mike King has been burnt down after permission was obtained to destroy the abandoned pen near Levin. 
The piggery made headlines in 2009 when it was one of the targets of an animal welfare investigation into pig farm practices. 
The campaign included a break-in by King and animal welfare workers at the piggery, and helped spark a law change in 2015, banning sow "stalls", which animal rights activists argued were actually cages that led to intense stress and injury. 
Local resident Chris Wilson said the blaze caught many people unaware and caused panic and confusion on Saturday morning. 
READ MORE: * Neighbours create a stink over piggery 
A fire service spokesman confirmed a call was received about 9.45am on Saturday alerting them to the blaze, in Kuku Beach Rd near Levin. 
Once there, firefighters learned it was a controlled blaze that had been organised in conjunction with Horowhenua District Council. 
Wilson, who lives in Kuku Beach Rd about 200 metres from the property, said he was not informed about the planned fire and it appeared none of his neighbours were either, including one woman who was "pretty upset". 
"I was sitting in the lounge looking at the sun disappear [behind the smoke]. 
"It would have been nice to have been told." Ad Feedback 
Wilson initially thought someone had set fire to the property but once at the scene heard people saying it was a controlled fire and that there were no dangerous materials such as asbestos. 
The property was not far from State Highway 1 and a number of cars pulled up near the property as people looked to see what was happening. 
Kuku Beach Rd resident Susan Taylor, who lives about 500m from the property, also said she was not informed about the fire. 
"I didn't notice until I pulled out of my driveway and saw the smoke." 
Once she got closer to the fire, it appeared all the right precautions had been taken and she did not feel in any danger, she said. 
"It looked pretty spectacular when you hit the main road [SH1] and looked back." 
Horowhenua District Council has been approached for comment.
